oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Ralph Emery Show: Conway Twitty - 1982-04-22 Parts 1-2-3
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: The recordings are of the Ralph Emery Show. The show is hosted by Ralph Emery (entertainer), and features Emery in discussion with his guest: Conway Twitty (musician). The show was recorded on April 22, 1982. The recordings are for parts one through three, of five parts, of Emery's interview of Twitty.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Conway Twitty; Ralph Emery
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:00) Conway Twitty performs a radio spot for the Ralph Emery Show -- (00:12) Ralph Emery greets the audience and discusses Twitty City with Conway Twitty -- (01:26) Emery inquires as to whether or not Twitty was still producing jeans and the story of Twitty City -- (05:06) Twitty reflects on how he discovered "Slow Hand" -- (05:59) Emery reflects on the wind in Twitty City, and Emery and Twitty reflect on the location of Twitty City -- (08:21) Emery asks Twitty to introduce Charley Pride's "I Don't Think She's in Love Anymore" -- (09:15) Emery asks Twitty to reflect on "The Clown" -- (11:18) Emery praises the college atmosphere of Twitty City, and Emery inquires about Twitty's privacy -- (14:28) Emery and Twitty praise John Anderson -- (15:09) Emery asks Twitty to reflect on his hat's availability and being available at Twitty City -- (16:15) Emery and Twitty perform outro statement, and Emery talks with his engineer -- (16:41) Emery and Twitty greet the audience and discuss Twitty City -- (19:03) Emery asks Twitty about the nickname 'The High Priest of Country Music' -- (20:15) Emery and Twitty discuss the last time Twitty saw Loretta Lynn, and Twitty discusses the backhoe working outside -- (22:08) Emery has Twitty reflect on the incoming country artists who will take residence near Twitty City, and both discuss "It Turns Me Inside Out" -- (24:40) Emery inquires about Twitty's relationship with his neighbor: Johnny Cash and Twitty City -- (27:35) Twitty reflects on how he saved "Redneckin' Love Makin' Night" for his last session -- (29:18) Twitty and Emery reflect on Simon and Garfunkel's country success -- (30:00) Emery reflects on the weather and invites Twitty to reflect on the beauty of Twitty City -- (32:10) Emery and Twitty say their goodbyes, and Emery jokes with his engineer -- (33:34) Emery introduces Twitty to reflect on what he uses the conference room for -- (34:52) Emery recalls the time he came to see Twitty City, and Emery and Twitty discuss "She Only Meant to Use Him" -- (37:09) Emery and Twitty discuss Twitty's future neighbor: Tammy Wynette -- (38:45) Emery and Twitty reflect on the charm of Twitty City and "Fifteen Years Ago" -- (42:38) Emery introduces Twitty City's 'zones,' and Twitty reflects on his tenth anniversary album -- (45:49) Emery invites Twitty to introduce Johnny Lee -- (46:32) Emery asks Twitty to reflect on how "Guess My Eyes Were Bigger Than My Heart" was on the cusp of Twitty's career change -- (48:41) Emery and Twitty say their goodbyes
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Twitty, Conway; Emery, Ralph;
